Award.AwardTitle: CSR: Small: Collaborative Research: Towards Collaborative Overlay Problem Diagnosis Using Evidential Reasoning and Adaptive Monitoring

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project presents a new paradigm-shift approach in fault diagnosis by investigating network problems without requiring any monitoring sensors or active measurements, and assuming little or no knowledge about the network. The goal is to develop accurate, scalable and cost-effective network problem diagnosis that reason about uncertainty in case of incomplete knowledge without intrusive active probing or network monitoring. This project investigates a novel approach that uses evidential reasoning based on user observations to analyze the end-user views as evidence and compute a combined belief for determining the most possible root causes in overlay networks at real-time. The project also investigates techniques to rank the overlay paths based on their quality. The reasoning results can then be fedback into adaptive active monitoring, and dynamic virtual assignment/reconfiguration systems to optimize problem monitoring and recovery, respectively.

Developing techniques and tools that enable sharing and analyzing end-host observations provide powerful diagnosing capabilities to service providers, system developers, and administrators to in problem determination, characterizing network conditions, configuration debugging and troubleshooting. These techniques are applicable on both overlay and traditional networks. This project enables trained workforce in this area through teaching and supervising students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to develop an accurate, scalable and cost-effective problem diagnosis system that  can reason about uncertainty in case of incomplete knowledge about the network.  To address these challenges, we developed a novel direction that uses evidential reasoning based on users observation and adaptive active probing to diagnose faults at real-time. We will use Dempster-Shafer  Theory as a foundation to analyze the end-user views as evidence and compute the combined fault belief for determining the most possible root causes of overlay problems. The reasoning results can then be feedback into adaptive active monitoring and virtual network  configuration systems to optimize the monitoring and recovery process.  Finally, we will investigated infrastructures and protocols that  allows for scalable and secure sharing of usres’ views.

The evaluation of our approach shows that proposed techniques contribute significantly to the improvement of the accurate of the proposed fault diagnosis. Our experimentation demonstrated that the detection rate can reach almost 90% for just 30% end-user participation and we only need 4-5 probes per component under insufficient evidences to achieve same 90% detection rate. Similarly, we also show the resiliency of our approach towards spurious evidence even spuriousness amounts to 25% of total evidence set. We also show that our solution is scalable to a network topology of size $1500$ nodes with greater than 90% accuracy and less than 10% false positive rate regardless of the fact if topology is real or synthesized.

To improve the robustness of our approach, we assume a malicious end-user and we show that we can accurately determine malicious activities. In summary, the analysis of our proposed fault diagnosis system is robust and can produce accurate result even with the existence of noise, malicious users and insufficient users' participation. This yields a deployable and practically usable system in real-life networks. 

Sharing and analyzing end-host observations provide powerful diagnosing capabilities beyond what service providers can traditionally  offer. Our proposed approach offers network providers/managers new means not only for problem determination but also for characterizing network conditions in security, configuration debugging and troubleshooting domains. This work will  resonate with  overlay system developers, administrators, and service and network providers who need to monitor and validate their control action effectively.  It will also provide valuable workforce contributions when we train students though research supervision and courses since these problem diagnosis issues are not adequately addressed in the current network curricula. A key educational goal of the project is to create teaching modules that can be used in undergraduate and graduate introductory classes. This project results in number of ACM/IEEE conference and transaction/journal publications, developing graduate and undergraduate materials  on "critical Infrastructure protection" course, developing a 3-hour tutorial on this topic presented in the graduate seminar.
